q2.value: Catherine Bortolon, Marcela Matos, Rosalie Altman

q3.value:
There is evidence that under some circumstances, shameful situations become central to their identity, life story, and, consequently to the way they relate to their world and others (Berstsen & Rubin, 2006; Matos & Pinto-Gouveia, 2010; 2014). Past experiences of shame that are central to one’s identity are more likely to lead to intrusive memories, attempts at avoidance, and are often associated with higher levels of shame and self-criticism (Berstsen & Rubin, 2006; Matos & Pinto-Gouveia, 2010; 2014). Moreover, previous studies have shown that shame memories (in particular those that are central to one’s own identity) and, more precisely, their traumatic impact on individuals’ life  are associated with psychopathology (Matos et al., 2013; 2014). 
The association between shame memories and hallucination-proneness has not been explored yet, even though research has shown that traumatic life events are associated with psychosis proneness and voice hearing.

Our goal is to investigate whether impact of past shame experiences (Impact of event scale), feelings of shame, and self-criticism mediate the relationship between centrality of shame memories and the experience of hearing voices in the general population (hallucination-proneness).

q4.value:
Overall, we hypothesized that the association between centrality (CES) of shame memories and both distress (anxiety and depression) and hallucination-proneness will be mediated by the traumatic impact of shame memories (IES; Boelen, 2012), external shame (Other as shamer scale - OAS; Matos et al., 2014), and self-criticism (SC; Pinto-Gouveia, et al., 2013). 
Thus, we will perform a sequential mediational model in which the following paths will be tested: 
- CES -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> OAS -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> OAS -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> OAS -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> OAS -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- Correlation between Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
Compared to our first pre-registration, here we simplified the presentations of our hypothesis. Moreover, based on previous studies by Matos and colleagues (2013) some changes were made: 
- We added a path between OAS -> SC - We added a path between IES->SC 
- We inverted the path between IES (Older hypothesis: - CES -> OAS -> IES -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness; 
New hypothesis: - CES -> IES -> OAS -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness

Changes were made based on previous research (e.g. Pinto-Gouveia et al., 2012; Matos et al., 2013) showing that the external shame and internal shame (constructed related to self-criticism) mediated the association between impact of event scale and psychopathology (e.g., depression and paranoia). These models are more in agreement with the theoretical models proposed by Gilbert (2003; 2007; 2010).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Data collection procedures: Individuals from the general population will be included in this study. Participants will be contacted via several channels including social networks, university website, and acquaintances of the authors and their colleagues with a snowball procedure. Requirements to take part in the study are to be 18 years old or more and to be ﬂuent in French. The study will be conducted online.

q13.value: Sample size calculation for SEM can be based on the overall model fit and/or based on the association among the latent variables. Gnambs (2013) and Preacher & Coffman (2006) created a website that generates a R code that can compute the minimum sample size required to achieve a given level of power for testing a covariance structure model using RMSEA (testing close to fit hypothesis). Based on the inicial hypothesized model, with α = 0.05, df = 4, desired power = 0.80, Alternative RMSEA = 0.08 (RMSEA H1 = 0.08 is generally interpreted as poor fit), and Null RMSEA = 0.00 (based on the study by Matos et al., 2013; Pinto-Gouveia, et al., 2014), a sample of 468 participants would be required. These calculations are based on the models proposed by MacCallum et al., (1996). The new model (df = 3), a sample of 569 participants would be required. Since we already closed the data collection, we had 500 participants who started the study, but only 436 who completed all the questionnaires.

q15.value: We stopped our data collection once we reached 500.

question.value:
1.	Shame memory priming: participants are requested to recall a specific or several shameful experiences from childhood or adolescence. Subsequently, they are instructed to respond to several questions asking for some details about their experience. 
2.	Centrality of Event scale used to measure centrality of shame memory, that is, the extent to which a memory for a shameful experience forms a reference point for personal identity. 
3.	Impact of event scale used to measure the traumatic impact of shame events in terms of avoidance, intrusion, and hyperarousal symptoms. 
4.	Other as Shame scale to measure shame. 
5.	Self-criticism scale. 
6.	Hallucinations: the Launay-Slade Hallucinations Scale was used to measure hallucination-proneness in the general population.  We are in particularly interested in the auditory hallucinations subscale. Additional questions measuring associated distress were added for items measuring auditory hallucinations. Finally, three additional questions were added from the Cardiff Anomalous Perceptions Scale (Bell et al., 2006) that target specifically voice hearing. 
7.	Revised Beliefs about voices questionnaires. 
8.	Depression, anxiety and Stress scale (DASS). 
9.	Socio-demographic characteristics including age, gender, and education level (the first two will be included as covariates).

Pearson correlation coefficients will be performed to explore the correlations between the different variables included in the study (Cohen, Cohen, West & Aiken, 2003). A sequential mediational model will be performed where we will test the following paths (see hypothesis): 
- CES -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> OAS -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> OAS -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> OAS -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> OAS -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 

Structural equation modeling (SEM) will be used to analyze the data. A Maximum Likelihood method will be used to evaluate the regression coefficients significance. If data is not normally distributed robust maximum likelihood will be used (Kline, 2013). The significance of direct, indirect and total effects will be assessed using χ2 tests. Bootstrapping resampling method will be used to test the significance of the meditational paths, using 1000 bootstrap samples and 95% confidence intervals (Kline, 2005). Outliers: Multivariate outliers will be screened using Mahalanobis squared distance method. Outliers will be excluded. Normality: uni and multivariate normality were assessed by skewness and kurtosis coefficients. Kline (2013) suggests that skewness ≤3 and kurtosis ≤ 10 indicate that the distribution is not severely non-normal. We will adopt this criterion in this study.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from the data when they failed at least two attention checks. We decided to include three attention checks (ex. Please reply "Always") to ensure that participants are not responding in a random way.

q23.value: Participants with missing data will be excluded.

Structural equation modeling (SEM) will be used to analyze the data. A Maximum Likelihood method will be used to evaluate the regression coefficients significance. If data is not normally distributed robust maximum likelihood will be used (Kline, 2013). The significance of direct, indirect and total effects will be assessed using χ2 tests. Bootstrapping resampling method will be used to test the significance of the meditational paths, using 1000 bootstrap samples and 95% confidence intervals (Kline, 2005). Outliers: Multivariate outliers will be screened using Mahalanobis squared distance method. Outliers will be excluded. Normality: uni and multivariate normality were assessed by skewness and kurtosis coefficients. Kline (2013) suggests that skewness ≤3 and kurtosis ≤ 10 indicate that the distribution is not severely non-normal. We will adopt this criterion in this study.

q3.value:
There is evidence that under some circumstances, shameful situations become central to their identity, life story, and, consequently to the way they relate to their world and others (Berstsen & Rubin, 2006; Matos & Pinto-Gouveia, 2010; 2014). Past experiences of shame that are central to one’s identity are more likely to lead to intrusive memories, attempts at avoidance, and are often associated with higher levels of shame and self-criticism (Berstsen & Rubin, 2006; Matos & Pinto-Gouveia, 2010; 2014). Moreover, previous studies have shown that shame memories (in particular those that are central to one’s own identity) and, more precisely, their traumatic impact on individuals’ life  are associated with psychopathology (Matos et al., 2013; 2014). 
The association between shame memories and hallucination-proneness has not been explored yet, even though research has shown that traumatic life events are associated with psychosis proneness and voice hearing.

Our goal is to investigate whether impact of past shame experiences (Impact of event scale), feelings of shame, and self-criticism mediate the relationship between centrality of shame memories and the experience of hearing voices in the general population (hallucination-proneness).

q4.value:
Overall, we hypothesized that the association between centrality (CES) of shame memories and both distress (anxiety and depression) and hallucination-proneness will be mediated by the traumatic impact of shame memories (IES; Boelen, 2012), external shame (Other as shamer scale - OAS; Matos et al., 2014), and self-criticism (SC; Pinto-Gouveia, et al., 2013). 
Thus, we will perform a sequential mediational model in which the following paths will be tested: 
- CES -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> OAS -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> OAS -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> OAS -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> OAS -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- Correlation between Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
Compared to our first pre-registration, here we simplified the presentations of our hypothesis. Moreover, based on previous studies by Matos and colleagues (2013) some changes were made: 
- We added a path between OAS -> SC - We added a path between IES->SC 
- We inverted the path between IES (Older hypothesis: - CES -> OAS -> IES -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness; 
New hypothesis: - CES -> IES -> OAS -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness

Changes were made based on previous research (e.g. Pinto-Gouveia et al., 2012; Matos et al., 2013) showing that the external shame and internal shame (constructed related to self-criticism) mediated the association between impact of event scale and psychopathology (e.g., depression and paranoia). These models are more in agreement with the theoretical models proposed by Gilbert (2003; 2007; 2010).

q13.value: Sample size calculation for SEM can be based on the overall model fit and/or based on the association among the latent variables. Gnambs (2013) and Preacher & Coffman (2006) created a website that generates a R code that can compute the minimum sample size required to achieve a given level of power for testing a covariance structure model using RMSEA (testing close to fit hypothesis). Based on the inicial hypothesized model, with α = 0.05, df = 4, desired power = 0.80, Alternative RMSEA = 0.08 (RMSEA H1 = 0.08 is generally interpreted as poor fit), and Null RMSEA = 0.00 (based on the study by Matos et al., 2013; Pinto-Gouveia, et al., 2014), a sample of 468 participants would be required. These calculations are based on the models proposed by MacCallum et al., (1996). The new model (df = 3), a sample of 569 participants would be required. Since we already closed the data collection, we had 500 participants who started the study, but only 436 who completed all the questionnaires.

q15.value: We stopped our data collection once we reached 500.

question.value:
1.	Shame memory priming: participants are requested to recall a specific or several shameful experiences from childhood or adolescence. Subsequently, they are instructed to respond to several questions asking for some details about their experience. 
2.	Centrality of Event scale used to measure centrality of shame memory, that is, the extent to which a memory for a shameful experience forms a reference point for personal identity. 
3.	Impact of event scale used to measure the traumatic impact of shame events in terms of avoidance, intrusion, and hyperarousal symptoms. 
4.	Other as Shame scale to measure shame. 
5.	Self-criticism scale. 
6.	Hallucinations: the Launay-Slade Hallucinations Scale was used to measure hallucination-proneness in the general population.  We are in particularly interested in the auditory hallucinations subscale. Additional questions measuring associated distress were added for items measuring auditory hallucinations. Finally, three additional questions were added from the Cardiff Anomalous Perceptions Scale (Bell et al., 2006) that target specifically voice hearing. 
7.	Revised Beliefs about voices questionnaires. 
8.	Depression, anxiety and Stress scale (DASS). 
9.	Socio-demographic characteristics including age, gender, and education level (the first two will be included as covariates).

2.	Centrality of Event scale used to measure centrality of shame memory, that is, the extent to which a memory for a shameful experience forms a reference point for personal identity. 
3.	Impact of event scale used to measure the traumatic impact of shame events in terms of avoidance, intrusion, and hyperarousal symptoms. 
4.	Other as Shame scale to measure shame. 
5.	Self-criticism scale. 
6.	Hallucinations: the Launay-Slade Hallucinations Scale was used to measure hallucination-proneness in the general population.  We are in particularly interested in the auditory hallucinations subscale. Additional questions measuring associated distress were added for items measuring auditory hallucinations. Finally, three additional questions were added from the Cardiff Anomalous Perceptions Scale (Bell et al., 2006) that target specifically voice hearing. 
7.	Revised Beliefs about voices questionnaires. 
8.	Depression, anxiety and Stress scale (DASS). 
9.	Socio-demographic characteristics including age, gender, and education level (the first two will be included as covariates).
registration_responses.q19.question:
Pearson correlation coefficients will be performed to explore the correlations between the different variables included in the study (Cohen, Cohen, West & Aiken, 2003). A sequential mediational model will be performed where we will test the following paths (see hypothesis): 
- CES -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> OAS -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> OAS -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> OAS -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 
- CES -> IES -> OAS -> SC -> Distress and Hallucination-proneness 

Structural equation modeling (SEM) will be used to analyze the data. A Maximum Likelihood method will be used to evaluate the regression coefficients significance. If data is not normally distributed robust maximum likelihood will be used (Kline, 2013). The significance of direct, indirect and total effects will be assessed using χ2 tests. Bootstrapping resampling method will be used to test the significance of the meditational paths, using 1000 bootstrap samples and 95% confidence intervals (Kline, 2005). Outliers: Multivariate outliers will be screened using Mahalanobis squared distance method. Outliers will be excluded. Normality: uni and multivariate normality were assessed by skewness and kurtosis coefficients. Kline (2013) suggests that skewness ≤3 and kurtosis ≤ 10 indicate that the distribution is not severely non-normal. We will adopt this criterion in this study.

attributes.title: Attachment Security Priming and Attributions About Future Romantic Partners’ Behaviors

q1.value: Attachment Security Priming and Attributions About Future Romantic Partners’ Behaviors

q2.value: Megan Fitter, Martha Davis Straske, Jude Cassidy, Jessica A Stern, Phillip R. Shaver, Mario Mikulincer, The Maryland Child and Family Development Laboratory

q3.value:
Research demonstrates that attachment avoidance and anxiety are associated with negative attribution biases (Hazelwood, 2012), and that these attribution biases mediate links between insecure attachment style and many negative relationship outcomes (e.g., Collins et al., 2006; Pearce, & Halford, 2008). A major limitation of these findings is that there is no basis for causal inference, and there are many alternative explanations for these associations. 

The proposed study will examine whether priming feelings of security leads to fewer negative attributions about partners’ behaviors, and whether this in turn predicts fewer negative implicit and explicit responses to partners’ behaviors. This study will contribute to the literature by: 

a) Replicating existing findings in an experimental context in order to strengthen theories in the attribution and attachment literature using recent methodology.

b) Examining risk factors for negative relationship behaviors, and possible intervention targets.

c) Using an implicit measure of relationship behaviors that doesn’t succumb to social desirability bias found in self-report and lab conflict tasks.

q4.value:
All hypotheses are about participants not in romantic relationships.

Hypothesis 1: Secure primed participants will report fewer negative attributions when responding to vignettes of ambiguous hypothetical partners’ behaviors.

Hypothesis 2: Reduced negative attributions will mediate a link between security priming and less negative implicit responses to ambiguous hypothetical future partners’ behaviors.

Hypothesis 3: Reduced negative attributions will mediate a link between security priming and less negative explicit responses to ambiguous hypothetical future partners’ behaviors.

Hypothesis 4: Participants’ implicit and explicit responses will be associated with each other, indicating predictive validity (see Cameron et al., 2012, and Greenwald et al., 2009, for details on predictive validity and relations between implicit and explicit responses of the same construct) in explaining behavior in a relationship.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Experimental design, between subjects. No counterbalancing is required.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two experimental conditions. Randomization occurred at the individual participant level.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data collection for the present study takes place on two occasions. First, students will complete a battery of online questionnaires including demographic information, the Experiences in Close Relationships Scale (ECR; Brennan et al., 1998), the Eysenck Personality Questionnaire Revised–Short form, Neuroticism scale (EPQR-S-N Eysenck et al., 1985), and the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSES; Rosenberg, 1979). These questionnaires take approximately 15 minutes total to complete. Second, all students who complete the online survey can then participate in the lab visit portion of this study.

During the lab visit, which will occur in small groups of no more than 4 students, participants will be given a description of the study procedures as part of the consent process, and a research assistant will answer any questions they have about the study. Following consent, students will be randomly assigned to study conditions, described below. All study conditions are entirely computer-based and approximately 30 min in duration. Students will receive course credit for their participation.

In all studies, participants are first randomly assigned to the secure or neutral attachment priming condition. Participants in the secure priming condition are asked to think about “the person in your life who you can most depend on to be there for you in times of trouble,” whereas participants in the neutral priming condition are asked to think about “someone in one of your classes who you do not know well and rarely think about.” All participants are guided through a 2-minute face visualization of the individual they have chosen, using procedures developed by Baldwin et al. (1996). Participants will be asked to write the name of the person they were imagining, and this participant’s name will remain in the top left corner of the screen throughout the study. Participants will be asked about their relation to the person they imagined for two minutes (e.g., mother, friend, romantic partner) at the end of the study for the purpose of possible exploratory analyses.

Next, participants will be asked whether or not they are in a relationship, for the purpose of determining which set of instructions they will receive (described below). This question is nested within a series of filler questions of neutral valence (e.g., “do you have any roommates?” “are you a psychology major?”) to draw attention away from the question and reduce possible priming effects of reflecting on one’s relationship status.

Next, participants will read four vignettes from Collins and colleagues (2006) about hypothetical future romantic partners’ potentially negative behaviors (e.g., “Imagine this person left you standing alone at a party where you didn’t know anyone”). Participants who reported not being in a relationship will be instructed to “imagine that these situations are happening with someone you may date IN THE FUTURE when answering the questions.” Participants who reported being in a relationship will be instructed to “imagine that these situations are happening in YOUR OWN relationship when answering the questions.” Following each vignette, participants will answer two sets of questions regarding their attributions about why the person behaved that way.

Following rating attributions about the event depicted in the vignette, participants will rate how likely they are to react in various ways (e.g., “snap or yell,” “ignore your partner”) using a procedure from Collins and colleagues (2006).

Finally, participants will complete a novel go/no-go association task (GNAT; Nosek & Banaji, 2001) to test implicit responses to hypothetical partners’ behaviors (Conflict Responses Go/No-Go Association Task; (CR-GNAT; Fitter & Cassidy, in preparation).

Please see the Measured Variables section below for more details on these procedures.

q13.value: 200 students who are not in relationships.

q14.value:
Our hypotheses concern participants who are not in relationships. This is because asking participants to imagine hypothetical romantic partners allows us to achieve our goal of measuring attribution biases. In contrast, asking participants to imagine their own romantic partners does not allow us to measure attribution biases as clearly. By asking participants about their own romantic partners, we are measuring a mix of attribution biases, and attributions informed by experiences with their partners. 

Our exploratory analyses concern both participants that are and are not in relationships. Thus, we will recruit participants regardless of relationship status. We will power our study to test our hypotheses. 

Monte Carlo power simulations conducted in Mplus indicate that 200 is an appropriate sample size to test our hypotheses. We will collect data from 200 participants who are not in relationships.

q15.value:
We plan to stop data collection after 200 students who are not in relationships have participated.  Since we will also be collecting data from participants who are in relationships, the sample size for our exploratory analyses will be greater than 200.  Following previous research with University of Maryland undergraduates in psychology courses, we expect about 25% of our recruitment pool to consist of participants in relationships. Therefore, we estimate that the sample size of our exploratory analyses will be between 250 and 300.  

If students are already signed up when we reach our target sample size, we will allow them to participate.  We will not allow new sign ups once we reach our target sample size, unless the following exception occurs.  Sometimes, there is a shortage of studies available to students and the University of Maryland asks researchers to allow more students to participate.  In this case, we may decide to allow students to participate until the end of the semester. We will not conduct any analyses until data collection is complete.

question.value:
Prime type: 

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two priming conditions (Secure or Neutral). For the priming conditions, participants will be asked to think about either  (a) “the person you can most depend on to be there to comfort you in times of trouble” (Secure Prime) or (b) “someone in one of your classes who you do not know well and rarely think about” (Neutral Prime). The experimenter will guide participants through a two-minute face visualization procedure developed by Baldwin and colleagues (1996). This procedure has been used in previous studies examining the effects of attachment security priming (e.g., Cassidy et al., 2017; Mikulincer et al., 2005) on a broad range of outcomes. Participants will be asked to write the name of the person they were imagining, and this participant’s name will remain in the top left corner of the screen during the study.

Demographics. Participants will answer questions about gender, race, age, and relationship status. 

Attachment Style. Participants will complete the Experiences in Close Relationships Scale (ECR; Brennan et al., 1998). This 36-item measure assesses attachment avoidance (e.g., “I don’t feel comfortable opening up to others”) and attachment anxiety (e.g., “I worry about being rejected or abandoned”). 

Neuroticism.  Participants will complete the Eysenck Personality Questionnaire Revised–Short form, Neuroticism scale (EPQR-S-N; Eysenck et al., 1985). This subscale assesses participants’ emotional tendencies (e.g., “Does your mood often go up and down?”)

Self-Esteem. Participants will complete the Rosenburg Self-Esteem Scale (RSES; Rosenberg, 1979). This 10-item measure asks participants to rate their feelings of self-worth (e.g., “On the whole, I am satisfied with myself.”) 

Attributions About Romantic Partner Behaviors. The first set of questions about attributions is Collins and colleagues’ (2006) explanations for potentially negative partners’ behaviors. Participants will rate how likely possible explanations are for the behavior in the vignettes. For each vignette, participants will rate 3 negative explanations and 3 neutral explanations. In Collins and colleagues’ (2006) study, negative explanations for partners’ behaviors showed good convergent validity with negative attributions on the Relationship Attributions Measure (RAM; Fincham & Bradbury, 1992), a well-validated measure of attributions for partners’ behaviors. 

The second set of questions about attributions is the Relationship Attributions Measure (RAM; Fincham & Bradbury, 1992). Participants will complete this measure in response to Collins and colleagues’ (2006) vignettes. We will ask participants to rate their agreement on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 6 (strongly agree) with statements that reflect six dimensions of attributions. The causal attributions subscale encompasses attributions of locus, stability, and globality (e.g., “My partner’s behavior is due to something about them”) and the responsibility attributions subscale encompasses attributions of intentionality, motivation, and blameworthiness (e.g., My partner’s behavior was motivated by selfish rather than unselfish concerns.”) The original validation study (Fincham & Bradbury, 1992) demonstrated adequate internal consistency across three samples with Chronbach’s α ranging from .55 to .88 for the subscales. The measure also demonstrated moderate to high test-retest reliability over three weeks. 

Explicit responses to partners’ behaviors.  Following rating attributions about the event depicted in the vignette, participants will rate how likely they are to react in various ways subscale (e.g., “Snap or yell,” “Ignore your partner,” “Criticize or complain”) using a procedure from Collins and colleagues (2006). This measure strong internal consistency (α =.93; Collins et al., 2006).

Implicit responses to partners’ behaviors. Participants will complete a novel go/no-go association task to test implicit responses to hypothetical partners’ behaviors (Conflict Responses Go/No-Go Association Task; CR-GNAT; Fitter & Cassidy, in preparation). Go/no-go association tasks measure implicit associations between a target stimulus (e.g., children) and an attribute (e.g., good). Researchers assess the strength of the association between the target and the attribute by measuring the degree to which distracter items (e.g., “annoying”) can be quickly discriminated from items that belong to the target category (e.g., “my child”) and the attribute category (e.g., “joyful”). Variations of the GNAT are frequently used to measure implicit associations (e.g., Anderson & Kaufmann, 2011; Kaufmann & Haslam, 2007; Sturge-Apple et al.,  2015). A variant of the GNAT has also been employed to test implicit responses toward one’s future child (Jones et al., in preparation). GNATs can achieve good reliability with 40 or more trials per block (see Williams & Kaufmann, 2012, for a review).

First, participants will complete two short practice blocks of the CR-GNAT (procedure described below). Next, they will be asked to imagine “Your partner didn't comfort you when you were feeling down.” After 30 seconds, the participants will be asked to think about how they would respond. Finally, participants will complete the CR-GNAT.

Three types of word stimuli will appear one at a time on a computer screen for 650ms each (stimulus time following Sturge-Apple et al., 2015). Words will belong to either one of two attribute categories (positive and negative) or the target category (the words “my behavior”). Words in the positive attribute category will be positive responses to the imagined upsetting behavior (e.g., “forgive,” “respect”), and words in the negative attribute category will be negative responses to the imagined upsetting behavior (e.g., “accuse,” “yell”).  The target category will consist solely of the words “my behavior”.

Subjects will participate in two positive blocks (one practice round with 14 trials and one real round with 42 trials) and two negative blocks with the same number of trials as the positive blocks. In the positive blocks, participants will be asked to press the space bar when they see positive words, or the words “my behavior” and to do nothing for negative words. In the negative block, participants will be asked to press the space bar when they see negative words, or the words “my behavior” and to do nothing for positive words. This task will yield two d’ scores, one for the positive block and one for the negative block. Higher d’ scores on the positive block reflect positive implicit responses, and higher d’ scores on negative block reflect negative implicit responses.

Negative attributions. 

Previous research using the RAM has demonstrated the two subscales (causal attributions and responsibility attributions) to be highly correlated. Thus, following previous research (e.g., Hazelwood, 2012; Pearce & Halford, 2008), we will reduce the subscales of the RAM into one index of negative attributions. 

Given that I use multiple measures of attributions (Collins and colleagues’ (2006) possible explanations for partner behavior, and the RAM), it is possible that some variables will be highly correlated. Following Collins and colleagues (2006) we will combine scores on the RAM with participants’ possible explanations for partners’ behaviors to create one final index of negative attributions.

We will examine gender, race, neuroticism, attachment avoidance, attachment anxiety, and self-esteem as potential covariates. Any of these potential covariates that correlate significantly with the outcome variables will be included as covariates in the models predicting each outcome. We will conduct independent samples t-tests to determine whether there are differences in the study variables between the secure and neutral primed participants. If any of these possible covariates are significantly associated with study variables, we will control for them in all principal analyses.

Hypothesis 1: To test our first hypothesis, negative attributions will be regressed on priming condition, and covariates. 

Hypothesis 2: We will conduct percentile bootstrapped mediation models to test our second and third hypotheses. Percentile bootstrapped mediation has a good balance between type 1 and type 2 error rates compared to the bias-corrected bootstrap and Monte Carlo approaches (Hayes & Scharkow, 2013; MacKinnon et al., 2004).
Priming condition will be entered as the independent variable, negative attributions will be entered as the mediator, negative explicit responses to partners’ behaviors will be entered as the dependent variable, and we will control for covariates.

Hypothesis 3: Priming condition will be entered as the independent variable, negative attributions will be entered as the mediator, negative implicit responses to partners’ behaviors will be entered as the dependent variable, and we will control for covariates.

To calculate implicit responses to romantic partners’ behaviors, we will use d’ from signal detection theory (SDT) to indicate performance on the GNAT. Before calculating d’, we will standardize hit rates and false alarm rates using the standard normal N(0,1) function. We will calculate d’ with the following formula: d’ = Z(hit rate) – Z(false alarm rate). To handle extreme values that cannot be standardized (0s and 1s), we will use the loglinear transformation approach (Stanislaw & Todorov, 1999). Prior to calculating the hit rate, I’ll add .5 to the number of hits and false alarms, and 1 to the number of signal trials and the number of noise trials. 

To remove method variance and control for general performance on the GNAT, we will follow previous researchers (e.g., Boldero et al., 2007; Sturge-Apple et al., 2015) and utilize residual scores. We will calculate a residual index of d’ scores for negative trials by regressing d’ scores for positive trials on d’ scores for negative trials and saving the residualized scores. These scores reflect participants’ performance on the negative GNAT trials, controlling for performance on the GNAT in general. 

Hypothesis 4. We will compute a Pearson product moment correlation between explicit responses to partners’ behaviors, and implicit responses to partners’ behaviors to examine the predictive validity of these measures.

q21.value: We will be using one-tailed tests for our hypotheses and two-tailed tests for our exploratory hypotheses at standard criteria of p < .05.

q22.value: We will exclude participants who only complete the pre-survey and do not attend the lab portion of the study.  We will use the GNAT as an attention check and exclude participants with negative d’ scores. This is because a negative d’ score indicates below chance performance (Nosek & Banaji, 2001). We will also exclude participants who have learned about security priming in the PI’s undergraduate attachment theory course. This is because these participants are at a higher risk of displaying demand characteristics, as they already know the general purpose of the experimental manipulation.

q23.value: We will use full information maximum likelihood to handle missing data.

q24.value:
Again, our hypotheses concern participants who are not in relationships. This is because asking participants to imagine hypothetical romantic partners allows us to achieve our goal of measuring attribution biases. In contrast, asking participants to imagine their own romantic partners does not allow us to measure attribution biases as clearly. By asking participants about their own romantic partners, we are measuring a mix of attribution biases, and attributions informed by experiences with their partners. 

We have several exploratory questions that include both individuals who are and are not in romantic relationships. We may add additional exploratory questions in the future. No exploratory analyses will be conducted until data collection is complete. 

1. Does the effect of security priming on attributions differ between participants who are imagining a current dating partner, and those imagining a hypothetical future partner?

2. Does the indirect effect of security priming on implicit and explicit responses to partners’ behaviors differ between participants who are imagining a current dating partner, and those imagining a hypothetical future partner?

3. For participants who are not in relationships, does the effect of security priming on negative attributions differ as a function of attachment anxiety and avoidance?

4. For participants who are not in relationships, does the indirect effect of security priming on implicit and explicit responses differ as a function of attachment anxiety and avoidance?

The second set of questions about attributions is the Relationship Attributions Measure (RAM; Fincham & Bradbury, 1992). Participants will complete this measure in response to Collins and colleagues’ (2006) vignettes. We will ask participants to rate their agreement on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 6 (strongly agree) with statements that reflect six dimensions of attributions. The causal attributions subscale encompasses attributions of locus, stability, and globality (e.g., “My partner’s behavior is due to something about them”) and the responsibility attributions subscale encompasses attributions of intentionality, motivation, and blameworthiness (e.g., My partner’s behavior was motivated by selfish rather than unselfish concerns.”) The original validation study (Fincham & Bradbury, 1992) demonstrated adequate internal consistency across three samples with Chronbach’s α ranging from .55 to .88 for the subscales. The measure also demonstrated moderate to high test-retest reliability over three weeks. 

Explicit responses to partners’ behaviors.  Following rating attributions about the event depicted in the vignette, participants will rate how likely they are to react in various ways subscale (e.g., “Snap or yell,” “Ignore your partner,” “Criticize or complain”) using a procedure from Collins and colleagues (2006). This measure strong internal consistency (α =.93; Collins et al., 2006).

Implicit responses to partners’ behaviors. Participants will complete a novel go/no-go association task to test implicit responses to hypothetical partners’ behaviors (Conflict Responses Go/No-Go Association Task; CR-GNAT; Fitter & Cassidy, in preparation). Go/no-go association tasks measure implicit associations between a target stimulus (e.g., children) and an attribute (e.g., good). Researchers assess the strength of the association between the target and the attribute by measuring the degree to which distracter items (e.g., “annoying”) can be quickly discriminated from items that belong to the target category (e.g., “my child”) and the attribute category (e.g., “joyful”). Variations of the GNAT are frequently used to measure implicit associations (e.g., Anderson & Kaufmann, 2011; Kaufmann & Haslam, 2007; Sturge-Apple et al.,  2015). A variant of the GNAT has also been employed to test implicit responses toward one’s future child (Jones et al., in preparation). GNATs can achieve good reliability with 40 or more trials per block (see Williams & Kaufmann, 2012, for a review).

First, participants will complete two short practice blocks of the CR-GNAT (procedure described below). Next, they will be asked to imagine “Your partner didn't comfort you when you were feeling down.” After 30 seconds, the participants will be asked to think about how they would respond. Finally, participants will complete the CR-GNAT.

Three types of word stimuli will appear one at a time on a computer screen for 650ms each (stimulus time following Sturge-Apple et al., 2015). Words will belong to either one of two attribute categories (positive and negative) or the target category (the words “my behavior”). Words in the positive attribute category will be positive responses to the imagined upsetting behavior (e.g., “forgive,” “respect”), and words in the negative attribute category will be negative responses to the imagined upsetting behavior (e.g., “accuse,” “yell”).  The target category will consist solely of the words “my behavior”.

Subjects will participate in two positive blocks (one practice round with 14 trials and one real round with 42 trials) and two negative blocks with the same number of trials as the positive blocks. In the positive blocks, participants will be asked to press the space bar when they see positive words, or the words “my behavior” and to do nothing for negative words. In the negative block, participants will be asked to press the space bar when they see negative words, or the words “my behavior” and to do nothing for positive words. This task will yield two d’ scores, one for the positive block and one for the negative block. Higher d’ scores on the positive block reflect positive implicit responses, and higher d’ scores on negative block reflect negative implicit responses.
registration_responses.q18.question:
Negative attributions. 

Previous research using the RAM has demonstrated the two subscales (causal attributions and responsibility attributions) to be highly correlated. Thus, following previous research (e.g., Hazelwood, 2012; Pearce & Halford, 2008), we will reduce the subscales of the RAM into one index of negative attributions. 

Given that I use multiple measures of attributions (Collins and colleagues’ (2006) possible explanations for partner behavior, and the RAM), it is possible that some variables will be highly correlated. Following Collins and colleagues (2006) we will combine scores on the RAM with participants’ possible explanations for partners’ behaviors to create one final index of negative attributions.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will examine gender, race, neuroticism, attachment avoidance, attachment anxiety, and self-esteem as potential covariates. Any of these potential covariates that correlate significantly with the outcome variables will be included as covariates in the models predicting each outcome. We will conduct independent samples t-tests to determine whether there are differences in the study variables between the secure and neutral primed participants. If any of these possible covariates are significantly associated with study variables, we will control for them in all principal analyses.

Hypothesis 1: To test our first hypothesis, negative attributions will be regressed on priming condition, and covariates. 

Hypothesis 2: We will conduct percentile bootstrapped mediation models to test our second and third hypotheses. Percentile bootstrapped mediation has a good balance between type 1 and type 2 error rates compared to the bias-corrected bootstrap and Monte Carlo approaches (Hayes & Scharkow, 2013; MacKinnon et al., 2004).
Priming condition will be entered as the independent variable, negative attributions will be entered as the mediator, negative explicit responses to partners’ behaviors will be entered as the dependent variable, and we will control for covariates.

Hypothesis 3: Priming condition will be entered as the independent variable, negative attributions will be entered as the mediator, negative implicit responses to partners’ behaviors will be entered as the dependent variable, and we will control for covariates.

To calculate implicit responses to romantic partners’ behaviors, we will use d’ from signal detection theory (SDT) to indicate performance on the GNAT. Before calculating d’, we will standardize hit rates and false alarm rates using the standard normal N(0,1) function. We will calculate d’ with the following formula: d’ = Z(hit rate) – Z(false alarm rate). To handle extreme values that cannot be standardized (0s and 1s), we will use the loglinear transformation approach (Stanislaw & Todorov, 1999). Prior to calculating the hit rate, I’ll add .5 to the number of hits and false alarms, and 1 to the number of signal trials and the number of noise trials. 

To remove method variance and control for general performance on the GNAT, we will follow previous researchers (e.g., Boldero et al., 2007; Sturge-Apple et al., 2015) and utilize residual scores. We will calculate a residual index of d’ scores for negative trials by regressing d’ scores for positive trials on d’ scores for negative trials and saving the residualized scores. These scores reflect participants’ performance on the negative GNAT trials, controlling for performance on the GNAT in general. 

Hypothesis 4. We will compute a Pearson product moment correlation between explicit responses to partners’ behaviors, and implicit responses to partners’ behaviors to examine the predictive validity of these measures.

attributes.title: Analyzing Students' Social Networks with ReadyEducation Data

summary.value:
We have received the first data from ReadyEducation, which has  data on 1,616 students from one school (includes retention/academic data, student-event network data, etc.). We are splitting the data into an exploratory and confirmatory subset, consisting of data on 808 students each (i.e., a 50-50 split with respect to students). We split the data using the rsample package in R (Kuhn, Chow, & Wickham, 2019), as shown in the attached knitted html file (ready_ed_datasplitting.html). We split students' user IDs into a list of students included in the exploratory and confirmatory sets, and these lists of user IDs will be used to filter out students assigned to the confirmatory data in the remaining datasets we work with (e.g., student-event data).

After we finish conducting exploratory analyses (with the exploratory subset), we will pre-register a confirmatory analysis plan, and then 'unseal' the holdout data.

Max Kuhn, Fanny Chow and Hadley Wickham (2019). rsample: General Resampling
  Infrastructure. R package version 0.0.5. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=rsample

attributes.title: The effect of a disfluency on memory following sentence comprehension

q1.value: The effect of disfluency type on memory following sentence comprehension

q3.value: In Experiments 1 and 2, we found that disfluencies have a beneficial effect on memory for immediately following linguistic material. That this effect was observed for all disfluency types. In Experiment 3, we will examine the durability of disfluency benefit to memory for the probe word by manipulating the position of disfluency in the sentence.

q4.value: If the disfluency benefit is enduring, memory for the probe words from the sentences with a disfluency in the beginning should be similar to the memory for the probe words from the sentences with a disfluency in the middle and in the end.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We have a within subject design with the following factors: 
disfluency type and disfluency position have 3 levels each
old / new at test is a factor with 2 levels

q9.value: The order in which participants will hear the audio sentences and see the memory probes will be fully randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform. We will only recruit participants who are at least 18 years old and have at least 95% acceptance rate on MTurk. Participants will be compensated $4 for their participation.

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis to estimate the sample size for Experiment 2. It indicated that in order to replicate an effect size of 0.12, we needed to recruit 160 participants. We increased the sample size for Experiment 3 to 200 to have a better chance of detecting the disfluency type * disfluency position interaction if it is in fact real.

question.value: We will manipulate two variables: the disfluency type (fluent, filler, pause), and the position of a disfluency in a sentence (initial, middle, final). At the memory test we manipulate whether the probe word is old or new (half old, half new).

The outcome variable is the binary response on the memory test. We will measure this by asking participants to indicate yes/no if each probe word is one they recognize (or not) from the sentences they had heard.

We will run 2 separate models: 1) to test for the effect of disfluency on memory; and 2) to test the effect of disfluency position on memory. 

The first model is a logistic mixed effect model with item status (actually old vs. actually new) as a factor, and then for old items, the presence of disfluency as a predictor. Random effects by subject and item, with random slopes if the model converges with them, and the response (old vs. new) as dependent.

The second model is a logistic mixed effect model for the old items only, and fixed effects are disfluency type (pauses vs. fillers), and position of disfluency in a sentence as predictors. Random effects by subject and item, with random slopes if the model converges with them, and the response (old vs. new) as dependent. 

Both analyses will be performed in R using the lme4 package.

q22.value: We will exclude the participants who failed to answer the microphone-check questions and the comprehension questions with at least 85% accuracy, the participants who participated in Experiment 1 or Experiment 2,  participants who completed the experiment twice, and non-native English speakers.

attributes.title: MENT-FOR
attributes.description: An explorative cohort study investigating the prevalence of deliberate self-harm behavior, and the Clinical, neurocognitive, psychosocial and criminological characteristics associated to deliberate self-harm behavior in forensic populations.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Extraverted and self-directed aggression: Deliberate self-harm behavior among forensic populations.

sample.value: Data collection will continue until we reach 100 participants.

analyses.value: Initially data will be analyzed with only descriptive statistics (demographic variables, self-harm yes or no, mean values from the self-report measures). Secondly, group comparisons will be made with Fischers Exact test, t-test and Mann-Whitney, and predictions using Logistic Regression, Partial correlation or Path analysis.

outliers.value: Outliers will not be removed from the analyses if it can be avoided. This group of patients is very heterogenous and the variation within the sample is large in most aspects. The differ greatly from the general population and this difference and variation must be showed and explained. That is why this research is so important.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable is deliberate self-harm behavior (DSH) which is  defined as self-injuries with the purpose of harming the own body, with or without the intention to commit suicide. 
DSH will be measured by using the questionnaire ISAS (Inventory of Statements About Self-Injury), and by questions asked in a structural interview. The specific questions from the structural interview will be presented in detail.
Other variables as childhood trauma, emotion regulation and externalizing behaviors will be measured with the following self-report questionnaires: Childhood trauma questionnaire, Difficulties in Emotion Regulation Scale and Externalizing Specturm Inventory. Information on these variables will also be collected through Medical files and the forensic psychiatric examination documents.

conditions.value: This is a cohort study and the participants will not be assigned to certain conditions. However, the main aim of this research is to find differences between participants with and without self-harming behavior. So in the second step of this research process, the group will be divided into two Groups: participants with self-harm behavior and patients without selfharm behavior.

hypothesis.value:
The overall aim of this project is to describe and investigate deliberate self-harm behavior in young violent offenders in the Swedish Prison and Probation Services and among Swedish forensic psychiatric patients.
There are three subaims that are presented as followed:
1.	Determine the prevalence of DSH among young adult violent offenders and forensic psychiatric patients and (article I & II), 
2.	Identify clinical, neurocognitive, psychosocial and criminological characteristics associated with DSH among young adult violent offenders (article I) and forensic psychiatric patients (article II) and, 
3.	Describe the function of DSH among forensic psychiatric patients (article III).

attributes.title: Effects of fiction on counterfactual thinking, perspective-taking, and moral reasoning

q1.value: Effects of fiction on counterfactual thinking, perspective-taking, and moral reasoning

q2.value: Mary Ann Ciosk, Ruth M.J. Byrne

q4.value:
- Participants in the experimental group who read a literary text will have higher “narrative transportation” scores (absorption in the fictional world) than participants in the control group reading a description of the same events (manipulation check)
- Participants in the experimental group will create more counterfactuals about how things could have been different based on a fictional characters’ actions (rather than external situational factors), than those in the control group.
- Participants in the experimental group will generate a greater number of “moral imagination” counterfactuals that imagine how a morally questionable action in the fictional narrative could be considered to be moral, than those in the control group.
- Participants in the experimental group will have higher scores on a perspective-taking test requiring participants to indicate what the characters are thinking and feeling and why they take certain actions based on inference from the text, than those in the control group.
- Participants in the experimental group will rate the characters’ morally questionable actions as more morally permissible than those in the control group. 
- Participants who have a high narrative transportation score will create more action counterfactuals, create a higher number of moral imagination counterfactuals, have higher perspective taking scores, and higher moral permissibility scores than participants who have a low narrative transportation score.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: A between participants two-group design, with an experimental group (who reads a narrative text) and a control group (who reads a descriptive text); each group completes 4 tasks (action counterfactual task, moral imagination counterfactual task, perspective-taking task, moral permissibility task)

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: The SurveyGizmo link was placed online at Trinity College Dublin School of Psychology on the 10th of February 2020. As of current preregistration, the online site indicates about 15 participants have taken part so far and their responses have not been accessed, downloaded or seen by any human.

question.value: Participants will be recruited through a link placed on the Trinity College Dublin School of Psychology research participation site for undergraduate students. They will be psychology students who are able to receive course credit for participation in the current study. The data will be collected through an online “SurveyGizmo” link.

q13.value: The target sample size is 102 participants, with participants assigned randomly to two groups (n=51 in each group).  We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .5 at the standard .05 alpha error probability for independent t-tests.

question.value:
- “Narrative transportation” will be measured by the “narrative transport scale” (a 9-item 1-to-7 scale), as a manipulation check.
- “Action counterfactuals” will be measured by categorising the counterfactuals participants create in response to the prompt “things would have been better for  if….”, as to whether the participant modified (a) the character’s actions or (b) the external circumstances. Categorisation will be carried out by the first author and an independent rater blind to the hypothesis, and inter-rater reliability will be calculated.
- “Moral imagination counterfactuals” will be measured by the number of counterfactuals the participant generates in response to the prompt “Please generate as many situations as you can where you believe the following would be morally permissible:  ”
- Perspective-taking will be measured by responses to 4 questions about what the characters are thinking and feeling and why they take certain actions, based on inferences made from the text. There will be 1 factual true or false question used as a comprehension check. 
- Moral permissibility will be measured by the participant’s ratings of 3 morally questionable actions that occurred in the narrative on a scale of 1 to 7.

Independent t-tests will be computed to test that participants in the experimental group (narrative text) show higher scores than the control group (descriptive text) on (a) the narrative transportation scale (as a manipulation check); (b) ‘action counterfactuals’, (c) ‘moral imagination counterfactuals’, (d) ‘perspective-taking task, and (e) ‘moral permissibility’ task. A bonferroni correction to the alpha will be applied for multiple tests.
